Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Nonlinear Carbon Nanotube and Nanowire Morphologies for Unique Nanoelectronics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is detailed study of the electrical properties of nonlinear carbon nanotube (CNT) structures, such as nanojunctions and nanocoils, for developing new types of nanoelectronic components including electrical switches, logic elements, frequency mixers, and nanoscale inductors. The approach incorporates: (1) controlled synthesis of CNT morphologies such as Y-junctions and nanohelices through chemical vapor deposition processes, (2) structural analysis through transmission electron microscopy, (3) investigation of growth mechanisms and defects, (4) study of the nanoscale electrical conduction mechanisms & device modeling, (5) layout of electrical and optoelectronic circuits, and (6) exploring the limits of device operation through high frequency measurements.

Intellectual merit: The proposed research into novel CNT structures may well usher in a new nanoelectronics technology through the use of new physical pronciples and the development of new classes of devices. Unique electrical properties have been predicted for nonlinear CNT structures, based on asymmetry at the junction regions, and portend a new generation of nanoelectronics. In preliminary measurements, novel inverting/switching behavior in three-terminal Y-junctions, and nanoscale inductive behavior in the nanocoils/helices was observed which forms the foundation for the work It could result into many new applications.

The broader impact would be: (a) the fabrication of nanoscale devices with the advantages of low power consumption, radiation hardness, and reduced heat dissipation over conventional silicon based technologies, relevant to civilian and military applications, and (b) outreach to the community in terms of conveying the excitement of novel science and device paradigms, through freshman seminars and new courses, along with undergraduate and graduate student mentoring. By working with Preuss High School, a student and teacher exchange program will be developed

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carbon based technology promises greater flexibility for potential use in electronics and photonics, as manifested, for example, through the extraordinarily large variety of carbon based organic structures that constitute all living forms. In recent years, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene have emerged as one of the foremost manifestations of potential technology and extensive research has been expended in probing their scientific characteristics for realizing such potential. As a variation on such a theme, the principal investigator (PI) and his group has shown that nonlinear varieties of CNT structures could offer unique functionalities at the nanoscale for future electronic applications, e.g., electrical switching devices in Y-shaped CNTs, nanoscale inductors in helically shaped CNTs, etc. The chief motivation has been to exploit the paradigm of “function follows form” allowing us to imagine, exploit, and create novel electronic, photonic, thermal and electromagnetic applications using such forms. 

In the project, we have sought to understand issues related to the practical utility of such nonlinear CNTs based nanostructures, and aspects related to their proper electrical measurement and interpretation.  Such investigations are in light of our previous realization that both intrinsic (e.g., pentagon and heptagon defects) and extrinsic (introduced due to entropic reasons, or processing) defects determine the behavior of CNT based nanostructured electronic devices. We then discovered that the defects in CNTs could present opportunities to exploit both structural and charge induced entities for new types of device technologies. We have then developed a new concept of quantum capacitance at the nanoscale relevant to carbon nanotubes, which could be used to significantly enhance electrochemical energy storage and have shown that the defects increase the effective area of charge transfer with potential applications to energy storage.

Community Outreach and Broader Impact  

The PI and his group have always been actively interested in disseminating the results of our findings as widely as possible and conveying the excitement of life in science and the laboratory to both students at various levels and the community at large. Consequently, a large number of graduate students (>10) and undergraduate students (> 25) have worked in our group, since the beginning of the project over the past six years, and have interacted and discussed issues related to nanoscience and nanotechnology. We have expended significant effort to encourage high school students to be involved in hands-on research, through Academic Enrichment Programs such as the McNair program. The PI received the campus wide diversity award, at UCSD and has recently been appointed Diversity Officer of the School of Engineering.

In terms of broader community outreach, the PI has published in archival journals, given several invited talks and organized colloquia at universities and international professional conferences, such as the Materials Research Society (MRS). The research on the use of defects in carbon nanotubes for supercapacitor applications and potential use in metamaterials garnered wide press coverage.

The work over the past six years has yielded several results in terms of proclaiming the utility of nonlinear elements and the constituent defects in various flavors for novel nanoscale technologies. We have realized the fundamental importance of the measurement and control of the interfaces and defects in CNTs.
